channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Over 100 Children Among 338 Killed in Aleppo Attacks This Week, W.H.O. Says
item.media:description: A child is pulled from the rubble of a building after airstrikes in a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, on Tuesday.
item.description: The World Health Organization said it feared many more would die from lack of treatment at hospitals destroyed or damaged by the government’s airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: At Shimon Peres Funeral, a Lineup of U.S. and Israeli Leaders Who Tangled
item.media:description: Former President Bill Clinton arriving at Mount Herzl Cemetery for the funeral of former President Shimon Peres of Israel in Jerusalem on Friday.
item.description: Often divided over international relations, but with so much in common, leaders from both countries have found it difficult to avoid meddling in each other’s politics.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Haitian Men Cut Off From Families as U.S. Tightens Entry Rules
item.media:description: “I’m hoping God makes miracles,” said Sandra Alexandre, with her newborn baby, Nova Vitoria Dieumercy, at a hotel in San Diego on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times
item.description: After the 2010 earthquake in Haiti, many Haitians were allowed into the United States on humanitarian grounds. Now, a sudden policy shift is dividing families.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Colombia’s 52-Year War Is Ending. Now Comes the Hard Part.
item.media:description: Willington, second from right, reunited with his family for the first time in years at a FARC conference.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.description: The country’s main rebel group, known as the FARC, made peace with the government. Photographs tell the story of fighters who must now decide how to reintegrate into society.
item.dc:creator: FEDERICO RIOS ESCOBAR and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Breaking Japan’s Glass Ceiling, but Leaving Some Feminists Unconvinced
item.media:description: Yuriko Koike, the first female governor of Tokyo, is a former television news anchor and defense minister who is fluent in Arabic.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Yuriko Koike, Tokyo’s first female governor, overcame sexism to win in a landslide, but she is backed by ultraconservative groups that think a woman’s place is in the home.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: South Korea Investigates Deaths of 3 Chinese Fishermen in Crackdown
item.media:description: A Chinese fishing boat caught fire during an inspection by the South Korean Coast Guard on Friday.
item.media:credit: Mokpo Coast Guard, via Associated Press
item.description: The men, suspected by the South’s coast guard of poaching, died when their boat caught fire shortly after flashbang grenades were thrown aboard.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: American Airstrike Killed Afghan Civilians, U.N. Says
item.description: An American spokesman said the military was investigating reports of civilian casualties in the strike in the Islamic State stronghold of Achin district, in Nangarhar Province.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What Is Russia Up To, and Is It Time to Draw the Line?
item.media:description: President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia failed to resolve their differences, including Syria, after 90 minutes together at a meeting in Hangzhou, China, on Sept. 5.
item.description: Russian airstrikes in Syria and cyberattacks have echoed some of the Cold War’s uglier moments. American intelligence officials wonder whether a grander scheme is at work.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Egyptian Who Hijacked Jet Is Ordered Deported From Cyprus
item.media:description: EgyptAir Flight 181, which was hijacked in March, at Larnaca airport in Cyprus.
item.description: Seif Eldin Mustafa had forced the EgyptAir plane to divert, claiming that he was wearing an explosive vest and demanding to see his former wife.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: International Court Takes a Stand With Ruling on Destruction of Antiquities
item.media:description: The rubble of the Temple of Bel in Palmyra, Syria, which was almost completely demolished by the Islamic State group.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague, in ruling that the destruction of cultural antiquities is a war crime, sent a signal, even if further prosecutions appear unlikely for the time being.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN and MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Chinese News Outlets Play Down Killings of 19 in Mountain Village
item.description: Censors have been hard at work taking down posts about the crime on social media that deviate from the terse account by the official news agency.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere: Reported Spike in Maternal Deaths Spurs Questions in China
item.media:description: A top health official in China said the country’s maternal mortality rate surged by nearly one-third in the first half of 2016.
item.description: An anxious, skeptical debate has broken out over an official’s announcement that the rate surged by nearly one-third in the first half of 2016.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: National Health and Family Planning Commission (China)

item.title: 2 van Gogh Paintings Stolen From Amsterdam Are Recovered in Italy
item.media:description: “Congregation Leaving the Reformed Church in Nuenen” (1884/85) had also been taken.
item.media:credit: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam, Vincent van Gogh Foundation
item.description: “Seascape at Scheveningen” and “Congregation Leaving the Reformed Church in Nuenen” were found during an inquiry into Italian organized crime, the Van Gogh Museum said.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Duterte, Citing Hitler, Says He Wants to Kill 3 Million Addicts in Philippines
item.description: Defying criticism of his country’s bloody war on drugs, the Philippine president escalated his provocative rhetoric with a reference to the Holocaust.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Battle to Define Democracy
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in September.
item.description: As in the United States during the current election campaign, the notion of what qualifies someone to lead in Britain is open to intense scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere: U.S. Lawmakers Urge Greater Scrutiny of Chinese Corporate Purchases
item.media:description: Wang Jianlin, chairman of the Wanda Group, hopes to buy at least a 50 percent stake in one of the “Big Six” Hollywood studios.
item.description: Sixteen members of Congress are raising questions over the foreign acquisition of American movie theaters and studios.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

item.title: World Leaders Gather to Mourn Shimon Peres, and Possibly His Dream
item.media:description: The decision by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, center, to attend Shimon Peres’s funeral on Friday angered many Palestinians.
item.description: President Obama and others paid homage to Mr. Peres’s tenacious search for reconciliation, yet the service made clear how elusive that idea has actually become in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Trade Ban to Protect Pangolins: Enough to Save Them?
item.media:description: A female pangolin in her enclosure at a zoo in Takeo, Cambodia. Her front right and rear left paws were amputated by poaching snares.
item.media:credit: Luc Forsyth for The New York Times
item.description: An international agreement now prohibits the commercial sale across international borders of the world’s most trafficked mammals. Enforcement is another matter.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species

item.title: Angered by 9/11 Victims Law, Saudis Rethink U.S. Alliance
item.description: Many Saudis see the passage of the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act, overriding President Obama’s veto, as irreparable damage to a long relationship.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas to Attend Shimon Peres Funeral, but Thaw With Israel Is Unlikely
item.media:description: The coffin of Shimon Peres, a former president of Israel, near the Knesset in Jerusalem.
item.description: The decision by Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, to attend the Israeli statesman’s funeral does not portend reconciliation with Israel.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Joseph Harmatz, Who Led Jewish Plot to Kill Germans After World War II, Dies at 91
item.media:description: Investigators in Nuremberg, Germany, examined the hiding place where arsenic was found in 1946 in a bakery that supplied captured SS officers.
item.media:credit: U.S. Army Signal Corps, via Associated Press
item.description: Harmatz, a survivor of the Vilnius ghetto in Lithuania, was the leader of a group that poisoned 2,200 imprisoned Germans by lacing their bread with arsenic.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Duterte, Philippine President, Raises Doubts About Military Alliance With U.S.
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Thursday.
item.description: Defense and diplomatic officials were facing a quandary after the president vowed to end military exercises with the U.S. and strengthen ties with China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Moscow Journal: Better Traffic Manners Where an Iron Fist Rules
item.media:description: A street in Moscow. In a city where traffic rules used to be viewed as optional, respect for crossing signals has grown.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: As with so much of what happens in Russia, interpreting the new civility on the roads depends on what you make of President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Antigraft Law Stirs Up Wariness Over South Koreans Bearing Gifts
item.media:description: Dining in Seoul. A new law has more South Koreans splitting the check, bucking tradition.
item.description: The measure, which affects public servants, journalists and teachers, will alter a country where meals, cash and other gifts have long been central to doing business.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Reykjavik Briefly Swaps Its City Lights for Northern Ones
item.description: The Icelandic capital went dark Wednesday night, after the City Council switched off street lamps and encouraged residents to turn off their lights.
item.dc:creator: PAULINE BOCK

item.title: Russia Rejects John Kerry’s Demands on Syria, Accusing U.S. of Promoting Terror
item.media:description: The site of an airstrike by government helicopters on a rebel-held neighborhood in Aleppo, Syria, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Syrian Civil Defense White Helmets, via Associated Press
item.description: Moscow’s escalation of anti-American invective came as United Nations officials warned of a “humanitarian catastrophe” in eastern Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD, SEWELL CHAN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere: Chengguan, Widely Despised Officers in China, Find Refuge and a Kind Ear
item.media:description: Chengguan, or urban management officers, confiscating fruit from a street vendor in Beijing in June.
item.description: In recognition of the pressures they face, a center opened in Nanjing that offers the urban management officers counseling and other support services.
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN

item.title: India Claims ‘Surgical Strikes’ Across Line of Control in Kashmir
item.description: Pakistan played down the early morning operation, which it said killed two of its soldiers and wounded nine, calling it a propaganda exercise by Delhi.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: North Korean Soldier Crosses DMZ to Defect, South Says
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers patrolling near the border with the North in January.
item.description: South Korea said officials were debriefing the soldier to determine his motive for leaving the North.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: What in the World: Lousy Libidos: Why Do Pandas Have So Little Sex?
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; photo by Enmyo/Shutterstock
item.description: Pandas have a slim window each year for mating, but even then, they often don’t know what to do, so scientists have taken to offering them guidance.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: What in the World: Medicinal Herb or Myth? Indian Official Proposes Hunt for Sanjivani of Lore
item.description: A state official wants to spend nearly $4 million in search of the plant, which is said to grow in the Himalayas and which a Hindu epic claims has the power to revive the dying.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Was Shimon Peres a Man of Peace?
item.media:description: Shimon Peres 1998.
item.description: In Israel, the late president is best known for his contributions to the military, not for the Oslo agreement.
item.dc:creator: TOM SEGEV

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why Britain Fails in Class
item.media:description: Heading to class at the Altrincham Grammar School for Boys last month in England.
item.description: Both the left and the right in Britain have made a mess of education by using schools for misguided social engineering.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why It’s Safe to Scrap America’s ICBMs
item.description: These missiles are expensive and dangerous holdovers from a long-gone era. It’s time to phase them out.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. PERRY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
